@psforscher I made a quick gist to get the data structure right (I think) so c1 and c2 don't vary within ID and covariate doesn't vary within group. It only took 109 seconds to fit, so I feel like something else is wrong with your data.

https://t.co/wWs5CJ0iH3

@psforscher (I'm not sure what type of variables C1 and C2 are. If they're factors with > 2 levels then that will make things a lot more complicated.) But I can't figure out why else your model would be taking so long.

@psforscher This model with no predictors takes ~20 seconds for me (I don't use brms, sorry)

dat <- expand.grid(
  ID = 1:20000, 
  rep = 1:20)
n = nrow(dat)
dat$group = sample(1:80, n, T)
dat$dv = rnorm(n)

m = lme4::lmer(dv~1+(1|group)+(1|ID), dat)

@rubenarslan @psforscher He's not, is he? Th formula in the first tweet is

outcome ~ covariate + c1 + c2 + (c1 + c2 | group) + (1 | ID)

@psforscher If you have ~400K observations, then that‚Äôs ~20 observations per ID, right? Is there substantial within-ID variance? What does the model look like with no predictors apart from intercepts? Is the covariate specific to each observation?
@psforscher How many groups and IDs per group do you have? What does the analysis look like for a single group?

@aggieerin I need to add a time series example like this. And nested groups. All we did was cross-classified models, so it's hard to extrapolate.
@aggieerin The 1 in "random = ~1|partno" represents the participant's deflection from the intercept (mean_panas, if I'm understanding correctly), but isn't in the Y formula. Does this make sense?

@aggieerin You need to add a random intercept term to your model for each participant:

part_i <- rnorm(number_group, 0, part_i_sd)

Y <- mean_panas + rep(part_i , 2)+
      slope_time*time_point + 
      slope_group*group + 
      slope_interaction*group*time_point + 
      error_terms

@aggieerin I'm not understanding how you're modeling the group-level random intercepts and slopes here. You seem to just have one error_term and fixed values for mean_panas, slope_time, slope_group, and slope_interaction.

I'm working on a shiny app to make this usable without R, but at the moment it just converts spreadsheets to YAML, which is an easier way to provide paragraphs of feedback.

https://t.co/Eu1Ixj2qZH

If you think this would be useful for you, please give it a try and let me know if there is anything else you'd want it to be able to do. We're been using it for exam feedback at @UofGPsychology for a few years now and it's been helpful for getting the files named for moodle.
You can also create visualisations of the whole marking file to include in the feedback or just for your own information. https://t.co/ZyrvDGRxZd

Once you have the template and spreadsheet set up, creating the feedback files is this simple:

markr::make_feedback(
  marks = "marking.csv", # or data frame
  template = "template.Rmd",
  filename = "fb/[class]/feedback_[student_id]"
)

Do you wish you could create student feedback documents dynamically from spreadsheets? Markr lets you render an Rmd template using the info from each row in a table and saves it to a filename you can specify.

I can use this to figure out which ones are numeric, symbol, or character, but then how do I select just the symbols?

rlang::exprs(...) %>% lapply(typeof)

@tomstafford The code is mainly:

y <- stats::rnorm(n)
z <- r * scale(x)[,1] + sqrt(1 - r^2) * 
    scale(stats::resid(stats::lm(y ~ x)))[,1]
yresult <- mu + sd * z

Where x is the existing vector and r is the correlation.

So you can maybe modify that for more than one x?

@elborgo9 @JamesSteeleII In my experience, not all (or even most) of the reviewers, but if anyone ever wants to replicate or build on your study, or include it in an evidence synthesis, they‚Äôll really appreciate the effort.
@elborgo9 Everyone should try an exact replication, computational reproducibility check, or meta-analysis someday to really understand how to make methods and results useful to others.
@elborgo9 Definitely wrongly. I agree that restricting the length of methods is unjustifiable, especially when most publication is electronic now.

This is only a good idea if authors, reviewers and editors acknowledge that there are *many* valid sample size justifications besides the N that gives you 80% power to detect the median effect size from meta-analyses, with an alpha of .05. @lakens‚Äô preprint is a good primer. https://t.co/UwYpA4lrhB

@bg_farrar Nice. How are you getting the labels rotated? I just get this: https://t.co/1bL4kgpWFO

@bg_farrar @CameronBrick To avoid that warning:

ggplot(df, aes(as.numeric(x))) +
  geom_density(trim = F) +
  scale_x_continuous(
    breaks = 1:5, 
    labels = LETTERS[1:5], 
    lim = c(0, 6)
  )

(I'm glad you'll be using bars, which are appropriate here, despite normally advocating #barbarplots ;)

@bg_farrar @rogierK @CameronBrick The bars are WAY better for me. Maybe reduce the width of the bars?

geom_bar(width=.4)

@rogierK @bg_farrar @CameronBrick The y axis in a bar plot IS the count, so directly translates to stacking all the "dots" on top of each other. He probably wants the y-axis to represent proportion, though, so set aes(x = xval, y = ..prop..)

https://t.co/kQLfUkNSvf
@rogierK @bg_farrar @CameronBrick geom_bar() is really the best solution here

@bg_farrar @CameronBrick I still think it's a bad plot type for discrete data, but if you're determined:

df = data.frame(x = factor(sample(LETTERS[1:5], 500, T)))

ggplot(df, aes(as.numeric(x))) +
  geom_density(trim = F) +
  xlim(0.67, 5.33) +
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = 1:5, labels = LETTERS[1:5])
@bg_farrar How are you setting up facet_grid to get the labels horizontal on the left?

@bg_farrar library(ggplot2)

df <- data.frame(

library(tidyverse)

X <- iris[, 1:4] # numeric columns

pairs <- crossing(a = names(X), b = names(X)) %>%
  filter(a < b) %>% # remove dupes
  mutate(k = map2(a, b, function(a, b) {
    cor.test(X[[a]], X[[b]]) %>% unlist()
  })) %>%
  unnest_wider(k) %>%
  type_convert()

I'm trying to make an example of how to run any analysis on every pair of columns in a data table efficiently. Is there a better pattern than below? I don't get why I have to unlist the output and type convert it; why can't unnest handle a list of lists? #tidyverse #rstats
